facts.text: Clause 3(c) of the Regulations states: No candidate who fails four times shall be permitted to continue the course.

facts.text: The Mysore Veterinary College, Hebbal, Bangalore, is one of the colleges affiliated to the University of Mysore for training students for the B.V.Sc. degree course.

anchor.surface_text: The Mysore Veterinary College, Hebbal, Bangalore, is one of the colleges affiliated to the University of Mysore for training students for the degree course in Bachelor of Veterinary Science (B.V.Sc.).

facts.text: Gopala Gowda was admitted in the year 1958 as a student in the First Year Course in the Mysore Veterinary College.

anchor.surface_text: Gopala Gowda--respondent in C.A. No. 565 of 1963--was admitted in the year 1958 as a student in the First Year Course in the Mysore Veterinary College.

facts.text: Gopala Gowda was declared unsuccessful in four successive First Year Course examinations.

anchor.surface_text: Gopala Gowda was declared unsuccessful in four successive First Year Course examinations.

facts.text: Controller of Examinations, Mysore University, informed Gopala Gowda by letter dated August 2, 1961 that he had lost his right to continue studies for B.V.Sc. course under Regulation 3(c).

anchor.surface_text: The Controller of Examinations, Mysore University, then informed Gopala Gowda by letter dated August 2, 1961 that he had lost his right to continue studies for the Bachelor of Veterinary Science (V.Sc.) course under Regulation 3(c) of the Regulations

facts.text: Gopala Gowda presented a writ petition in the High Court of Mysore praying to quash the order and permit him to appear for subsequent examinations.

anchor.surface_text: Gopala Gowda then presented a petition in the High Court of Mysore praying that, for reasons set out in his affidavit, the High Court do issue a writ quashing the order communicated by the Controller of Examinations in his letter dated August 2, 1961

facts.text: Bheemappa Reddy failed to satisfy the examiners in four successive First Year Course examinations commencing from April 1959.

facts.text: Mysore High Court held that Regulation 3(c) was beyond the competence of the Academic Council.

anchor.surface_text: We are informed at the Bar, however, that since the High Court decided the case on January 31, 1962, the two respondents were permitted to continue their courses of study and they have appeared for the subsequent examinations

holdings.text: The High Court was therefore in error in holding that the Academic Council had no power to prescribe Regulation 3(c)

anchor.surface_text: There is no warrant for restricting the expression maintenance of the standards only to matters such as minimum attendance, length of the course and prescription of minimum academic attainments. The High Court was therefore in error in holding that the Academic Council had no power to prescribe Regulation 3 c .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sections 22 and 23 confer broad powers on Academic Council to control teaching, courses, standards, and conditions for examinations, extending to weeding out unfit students after reasonable tests like four failures

holdings.text: Power to prescribe conditions on which a student may be admitted to the examinations necessarily implies the power to refuse to admit a student in certain contingencies for the power to admit to an examination implies the power to weed out students who have on the application of a reasonable test proved themselves to be unfit

anchor.surface_text: Power to prescribe conditions, On which, a student may be admitted to the examinations, in our opinion, necessarily implies the power to refuse to admit a student in certain contingencies, for the power to admit to an examination

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical implication from power to admit that refusal is inherent to maintain standards and control student progression

holdings.text: Failure by a student to qualify for promotion or degree in four examinations is certainly a reasonable test of such inaptitude or supervening disability

anchor.surface_text: And failure by a student to qualify for promotion or degree in four examinations, is certainly a reasonable test of such inaptitude or supervening disability.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Four successive failures demonstrate lack of aptitude, justifying discontinuation to prevent lowering of standards

holdings.text: Even though the view taken by the High Court was erroneous, having regard to the fact that the respondents were permitted to continue their course of study, the University not having applied for any interim orders pending disposal of these appeals, that any order should be passed in these appeals so as to deprive the respondents of the training they have received

anchor.surface_text: We are informed at the Bar, however, that since the High Court decided the case on January 31, 1962, the two respondents were permitted to continue their courses of study and they have appeared for the subsequent examinations and they were declared to have duly passed their second and third year examination

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exercise of discretion under special leave jurisdiction considering respondents' continued study, passed exams, lack of interim relief application, and exceptional circumstances

anchor.surface_text: Even though, the view taken by the High Court was erroneous, we do not think, having regard to the fact that the respondents were permitted to continue their course of study, the University not having applied for any interim orders pending disposal of these appeals, that any order should be passed in these appeals so as to deprive the respondents of the training they have received. These appeals are therefore dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dismissal without disturbing acquired rights due to equities and procedural history

anchor.surface_text: Even though, the view taken by the High Court was erroneous, we do number think. having regard to the fact that the respondents were permitted to companytinue their companyrse of study, the University number having applied for any interim orders pending disposal of these appeals, that any order should be passed in these appeals so as to deprive the respondents of the training they have received. These appeals are filed with special leave, and in the exceptional circumstances of the case, we do number think we would be justified, merely because we disagree with the interpretation of the High Court of the relevant regulation, in making an effective order against the respondents so as to nullify the results declared by the University companycerning them in respect of the second and third year examinations.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals dismissed without making any order to deprive respondents of training received or nullify their subsequent exam results, despite finding High Court erroneous.

The Mysore University Act, 1956 provides the statutory basis for the powers of the Academic Council, supporting the holding that the High Court erred in denying such power.
The Act grounds the interpretation of the power to prescribe admission conditions as implying power to refuse admission in contingencies.
The Act supports the holding that failure in four examinations is a reasonable test, as part of the Council's regulatory powers.
Powers in Section 22 ground a7's argument for competence to frame regulation
Section 22 supports holding affirming Academic Council's power against HC error
Supreme Court's disagreement with High Court on regulation subserving s.22 standards grounds holding that High Court erred in denying power to prescribe Regulation 3(c)

anchor.surface_text: There is no warrant for restricting the expression maintenance of the standards only to matters such as minimum attendance, length of the course and prescription of minimum academic attainments. The High Court was therefore in error in holding that the Academic Council had no power to prescribe Regulation 3 c .

Even though, the view taken by the High Court was erroneous, we do number think. having regard to the fact that the respondents were permitted to companytinue their companyrse of study, the University number having applied for any interim orders pending disposal of these appeals, that any order should be passed in these appeals so as to deprive the respondents of the training they have received. These appeals are filed with special leave, and in the exceptional circumstances of the case, we do number think we would be justified, merely because we disagree with the interpretation of the High Court of the relevant regulation, in making an effective order against the respondents so as to nullify the results declared by the University companycerning them in respect of the second and third year examinations.

anchor.surface_text: Even though, the view taken by the High Court was erroneous, we do not think, having regard to the fact that the respondents were permitted to continue their course of study, the University not having applied for any interim orders pending disposal of these appeals, that any order should be passed in these appeals so as to deprive the respondents of the training they have received. These appeals are therefore dismissed.

Even though, the view taken by the High Court was erroneous, we do number think. having regard to the fact that the respondents were permitted to companytinue their companyrse of study, the University number having applied for any interim orders pending disposal of these appeals, that any order should be passed in these appeals so as to deprive the respondents of the training they have received. These appeals are filed with special leave, and in the exceptional circumstances of the case, we do number think we would be justified, merely because we disagree with the interpretation of the High Court of the relevant regulation, in making an effective order against the respondents so as to nullify the results declared by the University companycerning them in respect of the second and third year examinations.
